Marching Band Methods.content: # Individual Instruction Date: October 23, 2020 Property: https://us02web.zoom.us/j/9643352012 Property 1: Topic: MUED 4344 - Marching Band Methods: Individual Instruction Time: Oct 23, 2020 10:00 AM Central Time (US and Canada) https://us02web.zoom.us/j/9643352012Meeting ID: 964 335 2012 ### **Individual Instruction - Oct. 23** [Untitled](Individual%20Instruction%20527ba0be9cb448518c5d44087154ae15/Untitled%20ff0abbcb612b4713911a2415b823a282.csv) ### **Individual Instruction Panel Questions** - In your experience, what is the greatest challenge young directors face when teaching individual students in a large ensemble like marching band? - In this same vein, what is the most challenging performance-related skill set to develop in high-school-aged marching band students? - With such a high student-teacher ratio, what are some strategies you prefer to assess student growth and development in marching band? - Over the course of your career, what is one consequential opinion that you have changed your mind on? Would your younger self be surprised by your change? - To your mind, what are the top two marching band or drum corps shows you've seen, performed in, instructed, or helped to design?

Please briefly share how you balance these two in your own program. - To your mind, what are the top two marching band or drum corps shows you've seen, performed in, instructed, or helped to design?

Technology.content: # Calendar MUED 4344 - Fall 2021 **Week 1** (Aug. 23 - Aug. 27) - [Ensemble Pedagogy](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Ensemble%20Pedagogy%2037d43c09ae28469da9ad322588cd803f.md) - Mise en Place & Fundamentals - Friday Lecture **Week 2** (Aug. 30 - Sept. 3) - [Ensemble Pedagogy](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Ensemble%20Pedagogy%2037d43c09ae28469da9ad322588cd803f.md) - General & Specific Skill Assessment, Repertoire Extraction, Integration - Friday Lab - Daily Drill **Week 3** (Sept. 6 - Sept. 10) - [Ensemble Pedagogy](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Ensemble%20Pedagogy%2037d43c09ae28469da9ad322588cd803f.md) - Assessment & Taxonomy - [Rehearsal Techniques](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Rehearsal%20Techniques%2034f1c0a2e5d34f6298cac2b645fbb4d7.md) - Scope & Sequence - Friday Lecture **Week 4** (Sept. 13 - Sept. 17) - [Rehearsal Techniques](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Rehearsal%20Techniques%2034f1c0a2e5d34f6298cac2b645fbb4d7.md) - Integrated Individual/Group Learning in Ensemble - Friday Lab - Daily Drill **Week** 5 (Sept. 20 - Sept. 24)** - [Individual Instruction](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Individual%20Instruction%20d8da2737dd9245819e4b301f125c988e.md) - Individual Learning (Tiered Scales) - Friday Lab - Daily Drill **Week 6** (Sept. 27 - Oct. 1)** - [**Marching Band](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Marching%20Band%2044917f71d8b245448b793a9d4ec4577a.md) & Orchestra Breakout** - Friday Zoom Chat - Marching Band (Individual Instruction) - Chavis - Hartwell - Guidry? **Week 7** (Oct. 4 - Oct. 8) - [**Marching Band](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Marching%20Band%2044917f71d8b245448b793a9d4ec4577a.md) & Orchestra Breakout** - Friday Zoom Chat - Marching Band (Group Teaching & Logistics) **Week 8** (Oct. 11 - Oct. 15) - [Individual Instruction](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Individual%20Instruction%20d8da2737dd9245819e4b301f125c988e.md) - Application (Region, Solo & Ensemble) - Friday Zoom Chat - Program Culture - Nunez (Tomball HS) - Easton (Tomball Memorial HS) - Shuttlesworth (Coppell HS) - Fincher (Clear Creek HS) **Week 9** (Oct. 18 - Oct. 22) - [Budget & Logistics](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Budgets,%20Logistics,%20&%20Administration%20c168db880c884b079babe863dd7577ca.md) - Friday Lab - Repertoire **Week 10** (Oct. 25 - Oct. 29) - [Budget & Logistics](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Budgets,%20Logistics,%20&%20Administration%20c168db880c884b079babe863dd7577ca.md) - Friday Zoom Chat **Week 11** (Nov. 1 - Nov. 5) - [Instruments & Equipment](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Instruments%20&%20Equipment%209f19163d423149dd8d1b08b413ec98c3.md) - Friday Lab - Repertoire **Week 12** (Nov. 8 - Nov. 12) - [Technology](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Technology%20186e84aad4eb4494ad149cc93f9ed506.md) - Friday Lab - Repertoire **Week 13** (Nov. 15 - Nov. 19) - [**Technology**](Course%20Units%209ebf688f340d4b0f94fc6290f16419e7/Technology%20186e84aad4eb4494ad149cc93f9ed506.md) - Friday Zoom Chat **Week 14** (Nov. 29 - Dec. 3) - **Synthesis** - Friday Lecture Comprehensive Notebook Viva Voce Final

Marching Band.content: # MUED 4344 Plan - Fall 2022 [MUED 4344 Synthesis Docs](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/MUED%204344%20Synthesis%20Docs%204d2efbcbbf47439cbc87a394e3393541.csv) [PLANNING](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/PLANNING%20146c16f8796444699a18e46f8ff6fc99.md) [Fall 2022 Roster](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/Fall%202022%20Roster%20e50d7794a1e54fab966c9de027f4156e.md) ![MUED 4344 QR.png](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/MUED_4344_QR.png) ### Mise-en-place, Music & Learning - **Mon., Aug. 22** - Attendance - Paper until after **Sept. 7** - Course Overview & Expectations - Syllabus - Assignment Cycle & Grading - **Wed., Aug. 24** - Goal vs. Fear Setting [Why you should define your fears instead of your goals | Tim Ferriss](https://youtu.be/5J6jAC6XxAI) [https://tim.blog/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/ted_ferriss_fear_setting_sample_slides.pdf](https://tim.blog/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/ted_ferriss_fear_setting_sample_slides.pdf) - Conceptual Mise en Place - Reduction, Structure, Interdependence - Occam’s Razor: [Occam's razor - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occam%27s_razor) - First Principles: [First principle - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_principle) - Archimedes Lever: [Lever - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lever) - Break Down Musical Concepts from Spring 2022 - **Technique** (Use Occam’s to help determine First Principles) - **Musicianship** (see above, avoid thinking about interdependence) - Reductive lens (and benefit) - Goal is to remember more with less information - structured learning/storage - Memory Palace is extreme example - explaining musical thinking is a more relatable example. - [Exit Tickets](https://forms.office.com/Pages/DesignPageV2.aspx?subpage=design&FormId=vboLF_CikEytSw6PDwxCWRS6KVT9hUBMv2Z5Rr59CJBURVBZOEM4NkNIT05LMVFDN1hYQlpOVVQzSC4u&Token=bf524a6fe4fb481aa31bd8e4e9d82817) - Daily completion-based grade - Larger grade from reflective writing - **Fri., Aug. 26** - Mise en Place - Introduce - Three central values: Preparation, Process, Presence - Key to success: keep your station clean - Application: - Ideal referenced - Reality referenced - Not just a todo list, but also a schedule and timeline - Extensible! - Frame for course - How to prepare - How to refine - How to repair - How to make habits - Why? - *When the time is on you, start, and the pressure will be off.* - Prep, Planning, and *Mise* all have a goal embedded - Questions to Help Determine This: - What can my students do well? - Where do my students struggle? - What is the next logical step - Break it down into fundamentals - Deploy - Real-world application - String Orchestra [2018 RRHS String Orchestra Pre-UIL - Kleine Serenade](https://youtu.be/ZfSbhqFraew) - Wind Band [Symphonic Band UIL 2022](https://youtu.be/EDUledfHGcI) ### Ensemble Pedagogy - **Mon., Aug. 29** - **Simplicity** allows you to see where things might (or might not) intersect or interact, and how. - Leverage - Razor **Ensemble Pedagogy - CONVERSATION** - **What is the goal of musical development in an ensemble setting?** - Our yardsticks matter, because they inform our expectations and our goals. - **What is the goal of musical development at an individual level?** - The ‘how’ of developing can be extracted from the habits of professionals. - **What are skills and experiences that they share?** - The fundamental elements of music remain the same, no matter the instrument or level of interaction (self, group). - They both have a robust bodies of expert experience to pull from. **Logistical Angle** - What are the demands placed on my and my student’s time? - What kind of skills do they need to do those things well? - What kind of pace does one need to achieve those skills to coincide with the need for those skills? **Educational Angle** - What kind of musical and social development do I want for my students? - What kind of formal and informal evaluations are my students and I receiving? **Musical/Aesthetic Angle** - What are my educational, artistic, and musical values? - What sorts of experiences do I think are valuable for my students? **Comparison (start each at 0:56)** **UNT Recording** [O Mensch, bewein dein Sünde groß, BWV 622 (Arr. P. Grainger)](https://youtu.be/_E1r03cHCww) **UH Recording** [03 O, Man, now weep for thy great Sin.mp3](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/03_O_Man_now_weep_for_thy_great_Sin.mp3) **Soapbox:** Frame ensemble pedagogy not as an aesthetic outcome, but a tool to enhance student learning and potential aesthetic outcome(s) through a development-focused, mastery-driven curriculum. - **Wed., Aug. 31** **POWERPOINT** [MUED 4344 Ens. Ped.key](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/MUED_4344_Ens._Ped.key) **EXAMPLES** - High School: [Lake Highlands HS Band, Symphonic Metamorphosis](https://youtu.be/T2Gx244iuJI) - College: [UMich Symphony Band - Paul Hindemith - "March" from Symphonic Metamorphosis (1943)](https://youtu.be/8coODXf3xKs) - Professional: [Symphonic Metamorphosis of Themes of Carl Maria von Weber: IV. Marsch](https://youtu.be/D2lZQW768fM) - **Fri., Sep. 2** [MUED 4344 Mise Placemat F22.pdf](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/MUED_4344_Mise_Placemat_F22.pdf) Using the Tools: Simplification, *Mise en Place*, Ensemble Pedagogy - Select work - Listen to work - Break down work - Technical Components - Musical Components - Difficulty/Complexity/Challenge - Requirements of **work** - Skills/Weaknesses of the **ensemble** - Priority List - Lesson Planning Band Work: *Listen to the Lambs* - Douglas [Listen to the Lambs - Marie A. Douglas](https://www.marieadouglas.com/listen-to-the-lambs) String Work: *Warrior Legacy* - Newbold [Warrior Legacy by Soon Hee Newbold - Orchestra (Score & Sound)](https://youtu.be/j-lMGVSk0rM) ### Ensemble Pedagogy & Literature Mon., Sep. 5 - **NO CLASS MEETING, LABOR DAY ✊🏼** Wed., Sep. 7 Fri., Sep. 9 ### Ensemble Pedagogy & Literature Mon., Sep. 12 Wed., Sep. 14 Fri., Sep. 16 ### Rehearsal Techniques & Individual Instruction - **Mon., Sep. 19** - Assessing Student Performance EXAMPLES ['Eagle Crest March' MJHS Non-Varsity Band](https://youtu.be/paSz6k4EXvk) [2019 UIL BHS Non Varsity Band](https://youtu.be/95K50rqotZk?t=39) [O'Connor Orchestra Non-Varsity U.I.L. 2021 Concert](https://youtu.be/hK2b0Z-_naI?t=53) [2019 UIL CHS Non Varsity Band](https://youtu.be/AyH6f42kDgU?t=39) - How to Listen - Narrow Focus vs. Wide Focus - Familiar vs. unfamiliar timbres - Error detection - Comparison vs. history || comparison vs. exemplar - What to Listen For - Focus of lesson/day - Common errors vs. points of weakness - Error Types - Binary Errors (e.g., right vs. wrong notes) - Continuum Errors (e.g., tone, musicality) - How to Respond? - Respond to what you hear, not what you think you heard - Respond in a way that identifies the problem and its cause, pointing to a solution. - **Wed., Sep. 21** - Assessment & Remediation Loop - What we actually hear vs. what we think we hear - Almost all musical performance is a combination of multiple correlated skills - Perceive - diagnose - assess - prescribe - repeat - **Fri., Sep. 23** - Structuring Rehearsal, Structuring Feedback - Teaching Frames ### Rehearsal Techniques & Individual Instruction - **Mon., Sep. 26** - Rehearsal ‘Ears’ - Perceive - diagnose - assess - prescribe - repeat - Rehearsal Prep - Mise en Place - Frequency → Priority - Lesson Plans vs. Curriculum - Weather vs. Climate - Wed., Sep. 28 - Assessment & Remediation Loop - PRACTICE - Lesson Plans vs. Curriculum - Weather vs. Climate [MUED 4340 Mise Placement 0.9.docx](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/MUED_4340_Mise_Placement_0.9.docx) - Lab Ensemble Prep - Score - Mise-en-place - First Draft Plan - Listening w/ mise - Second Draft Plan - Teaching Frames [La Madre De Los Gatos Score.pdf](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/La_Madre_De_Los_Gatos_Score.pdf) [La Madre De Los Gatos by Brian Beck](https://youtu.be/MNlX1zN5tog?t=15) - Fri., Sep. 30 - **Lab Ensemble** ### Marching Band Mon., Oct. 3 Wed., Oct. 5 Fri., Oct. 7 ### Marching Band Mon., Oct. 10 Wed., Oct. 12 Fri., Oct. 14 ### Budget, Logistics, & Admin. [Week of Oct. 17](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/Week%20of%20Oct%2017%2022f60f0cd02c45068d23606918df5704.md) ### Budget, Logistics, & Admin [Week of Oct. 24](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/Week%20of%20Oct%2024%207c4aeb18a24f496d8e0cc2a586f507e6.md) ### Instruments & Equipment [Week of Oct. 31](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/Week%20of%20Oct%2031%20122b6125245c43abafed0d3d3d6c07bf.md) ### Instruments & Equipment [Week of Nov. 7](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202022%20a8700b80477347dc8fe9cc68272ccc6a/Week%20of%20Nov%207%205573a1ebc8e14bed9d2da0c902264fe5.md) ### Technology Mon., Nov. 14 Wed., Nov. 16 Fri., Nov. 18 ### Technology Mon., Nov. 21 - Zoom Meeting ([*Robby Burns](https://www.notion.so/Robby-Burns-62b492e77cdd4c7c8a36706f487ac241?pvs=21)?*) Wed., Nov. 23 - **NO CLASS MEETING, THANKSGIVING 🦃** Fri., Nov. 25 - **NO CLASS MEETING, THANKSGIVING 🦃** ### SYNTHESIS **Mon., Nov. 28** - Technology Synthesis - **Prompts** “Your campus is pushing for technology integration into every classroom, every day. You are in the Spring Semester, preparing for UIL Concert & Sightreading, playing pieces that are developmentally appropriate for your students but are pushing them to deepen their musical thinking and technical skills. Describe one way that you could accomplish this while enhancing your existing rehearsal process and priorities.” “Over the past two years your program has grown exponentially - from 50 students to 150! Your district will only create additional FTE positions when the average student/teacher ratio is 75:1 for more than two years. You have at least one year before an additional position is approved and another before that person could be hired and start work. Describe how you could use technology to extend and enhance your individual student instruction over the next two years.” - **Process** - Students randomly assigned prompt 1 or 2 - Students work on their responses (5 minutes) - Create groups of 4-5 students (homogenous) - Students share and edit their responses (10 minutes) - Students vote on best of each group (2 minutes) - Each group presents one solution (20 minutes) **Wed., Nov. 30** - Logistics & Administration Synthesis - Prompts - Process - Sharing **Fri., Dec. 2** - Instructional Synthesis - Prompts - Process - Sharing

Marching Band.content: # Fall 2021 - Zoom Panel Guests **Invitation Email:** This semester, I am teaching a course whose focus is the synthesis and application of all our MUED student's experiences and learning into High School Band and Orchestra. Marching band is an obvious and important aspect of this course for the Band-oriented students, and I would love for our students to learn by interacting (virtually) with you! We don't currently have a marching-band-specific course in our curriculum, so I am positioning these topics are seed kernels that will help the students grow their skills through informed, thoughtful, professional experience. I've identified a topic that I think, even among your numerous talents, your experience, achievements, and growth place you among rarified company. It's imperfect but better than avoiding the topic altogether. Your session would be on a Friday, between 10:00 and 11:00 am. Because I know that the Fall is a busy time, I am sharing a Doodle poll with you ([linked here](https://doodle.com/meeting/participate/id/lej2YnRe)) to specify the dates that you are available to talk with the students. Would you please let me know your thoughts by Friday, August 13th? I will compare everyone's availability and communicate a final date with you no later than Friday, August 20th. I realize that may conflict with your teaching schedule or present other consistent conflicts — if you're not available, no worries at all! Just let me know by replying to this email, and I'll add you to our queue for future semesters! Below is a blurb that I will share with our students about the session topic. It should help to frame the angle that I am taking with the class. Thank you for considering this request, and please let me know if you have any questions or concerns! I'm looking forward to working with you and to our students growing through their interactions with you! Have a great weekend; thanks again! Cory [Marching Band Program Culture](Fall%202021%20-%20Zoom%20Panel%20Guests%20737b58d594424e6fbc8f082ae3bb306f/Marching%20Band%20Program%20Culture%2033bef910d396481fb65ba1154797ad6b.csv) ## Full Orchestra Good evening! Thank you **so much** for agreeing to spend time with my class next week! The scope of this course is very, very broad - incorporating all things band and all things orchestra. To that end, speaking with great teachers like you — who are doing the work and doing it at a very high level — is a fantastic way to both contextualize the things we talk about in class and help the students prioritize topics and tools through a real-world perspective. Also, nobody ever suffered by learning from awesome musicians and teachers. 🙂 Because the course is so broad, I think it would be good to narrow our scope to addressing the **coordination**, **communication**, **instruction**, and **logistics** of Full Orchestra from each of your distinct perspectives. It's less common in our field for different disciplines to collaborate like this, and your expertise and insight will go a long way to helping students extend the tools we address in class into this setting! The Zoom link is below. I will introduce each of you to the class and allow you to share a quick biographical background with the students. From there, I have included a list of ’starter questions’ that will serve to begin the conversation: - What has been the most challenging aspect of Full Orchestra for you to navigate or master? - What sort of timeline and communication do you think works best for teaching Full Orchestra? Does one teacher take the lead? Does equal effort and collaboration work better? Students will have the chance to ask questions here. There are 33 of them, so I suspect we'll have quite the potpourri of things to discuss! I'll save the final question below for the last 5 minutes (*unless a student asks a similar-enough question before that*). - What have been the biggest rewards (expected or unexpected) you've had from teaching Full Orchestra? **Thank you, again,** for your generosity! I’m looking forward to you spending time with us!! Cory [Klein Oak HS - Oct. 29](Fall%202021%20-%20Zoom%20Panel%20Guests%20737b58d594424e6fbc8f082ae3bb306f/Klein%20Oak%20HS%20-%20Oct%2029%2021ac19d7193743caa5a53a80511dda3a.csv) [Westwood HS - Nov. 22](Fall%202021%20-%20Zoom%20Panel%20Guests%20737b58d594424e6fbc8f082ae3bb306f/Westwood%20HS%20-%20Nov%2022%2036ed3a15b4404c7a9d68101ce5acd647.csv)

Classroom Technology.content: # MUED 4344 Plan - Fall 2023 ## Introduction & Technology - **August 21** (Monday) - Introduction, Mise en Place, Student Technology - Names around the room - Individual Questionnaire: [https://forms.office.com/r/XA0LvYZpTM](https://forms.office.com/r/XA0LvYZpTM) - Technology - Attendance - Exit Tickets - Canvas - Analog Technology - Mise en Place - Tools for Thinking - **August 23** (Wednesday) - Classroom Technology Technology Synthesis - **Prompts** “Your campus is pushing for technology integration into every classroom, every day. You are in the Spring Semester, preparing for UIL Concert & Sightreading, playing pieces that are developmentally appropriate for your students but are pushing them to deepen their musical thinking and technical skills. Describe one way that you could accomplish this while enhancing your existing rehearsal process and priorities.” “Over the past two years, your program has grown exponentially - from 50 students to 150! Your district will only create additional FTE (Full-Time Equivalent) positions when the average student/teacher ratio is 75:1 for more than two years. You have at least one year before an additional position is approved and another before that person can be hired and start work. Rehearsal Techniques.content: # Daily Notes ### Week 1 - **8.23.2021** - **Syllabus** [MUED 4344 Fall 2021 SYLLABUS.pdf](Daily%20Notes%2001eb7a0f9a3a4c119e20c9c6c3cfeb24/MUED_4344_Fall_2021_SYLLABUS.pdf) - **Course Objectives** - Reference syllabus - **Course Procedures** - Attendance - Discussion - If/then framework - Face-to-face & Virtual - Assignment submission - If/then framework - TEAMS vs. Blackboard - Communication & Office Hours - 24-hour email response - Scheduled office hours - **Course Structure** - **Intake vs. Workshop** - Information Sessions ****= Lectures w/ PowerPoint - Application Sessions = Sandbox & Application of **Intake** - Assignments & Projects = Refining & expanding on information & application - **Background** - Daily Work - **Foreground** - Major Projects - Final Project - **How and Why to Take Notes** - **Why?** - **Tools** - Local / Non-Cloud - **Paper Notebook** - **Obsidian** ([https://obsidian.md/](https://obsidian.md/)) - LogSeq - Hybrid Local/Cloud - **Notion** ([https://www.notion.so/](https://www.notion.so/)) - **Evernote** ([https://evernote.com/](https://evernote.com/)) - **OneNote** ([https://www.onenote.com/](https://www.onenote.com/)) - Athens - Fully Cloud-Based - **Roam** ([https://roamresearch.com/](https://roamresearch.com/)) - **Google Keep** ([https://keep.google.com/](https://keep.google.com/)) - *Mise en Place* - Definition: a culinary process in which ingredients are prepared and organized (as in a restaurant kitchen) before cooking - Translation to MUED contexts: preparing materials and processes before teaching to ensure ready access and familiarity with both *what* is being taught and *how* one plans to teach it - **Activity:** "What sorts of things in music and teaching benefit from a *mise en place* mindset? What things do not?" - **8.25.2021** - *Mise en Place* - Definition: a culinary process in which ingredients are prepared and organized (as in a restaurant kitchen) before cooking - Translation to MUED contexts: preparing materials and processes before teaching to ensure ready access and familiarity with both *what* is being taught and *how* one plans to teach it - **Activity:** "What sorts of things in music and teaching benefit from a *mise en place* mindset? What things do not?" **What are the things we need for teaching?** - Physical items & organization - Physical processes & preparation - Conceptual items & processes **In general, how do we teach?** - Teaching Loops - Teaching ≠ Telling (only) **What things inform how we approach teaching?** - Equipment & Physical Items - Knowledge & Experience - Time & Support - Students & Learning **Knowing this, how do we decide what (and how) to teach?** - *a priori* knowledge - inferred knowledge - accumulated/statistically-derived knowledge **What, then, does planning look like as a music teacher?** **Draw connections to *Mise en Place*** - **8.27.2021** Planning & Experience - Assessment and expectation - Statistical learning - Assessment Exercise **Orchestra** [Lassiter High School Orchestra: Irish Legend](https://youtu.be/EYely-I-beo) **Band** [Symphony No. 1, "Jeremiah": II. Profanation (arr. F. Bencriscutto)](https://youtu.be/S4xjk2maogs) ### Week 2 - **8.30.2021 - Information** ### Music & Human Learning What are the different ways that we learn? - Doing - Watching - Reading - Imagining What are some different ways we think about learning? - Behaviorism - Behaviorism focuses on the idea that all behaviors are learned through interaction with the environment. This learning theory states that behaviors are learned from the environment, and says that innate or inherited factors have very little influence on behavior. - Cognitivism - Cognitivism is a learning theory that focusses on how information is received, organized, stored and retrieved by the mind. It uses the mind as an information processor, like a computer. Therefore, cognitivism looks beyond observable behavior, viewing learning as internal mental processes. - Constructivism - Constructivism is based on the idea that people actively construct or make their own knowledge, and that reality is determined by your experiences as a learner. Basically, learners use their previous knowledge as a foundation and build on it with new things that they learn. How do we treat learning? ([OECD](https://www.oecd.org/about/) Definitions) - Informal - Informal learning is never organized, has no set objective in terms of learning outcomes and is never intentional from the learner’s standpoint. Often it is referred to as learning by experience or just as experience. - Formal - Formal learning is always organized and structured, and has learning objectives. From the learner’s standpoint, it is always intentional: i.e. the learner’s explicit objective is to gain knowledge, skills and/or competences. How does music **often** fit in here? - The vast majority of music being performed in the world **right now** is the product of informal learning, across the vast majority of cultures and traditions. - Some instances of **formal** learning in music: - Western-classical art music (John Drummond) - Indian/South Asian Classical music (apprenticeship model) - Seeking to learn non-familiar styles or genres (hybrid model) What is the role of **school** in this? - Codified curriculum - the best and most important - *What you leave out is sometimes more telling than what you include* - Systematized deployment - education at scale - *Humans aren't one-size-fits-all where learning is concerned* - Guiding Ethos: - "The business of the educator—whether parent or teacher—is to see to it that the greatest possible number of ideas acquired by children and youth are acquired in such a vital way that they become moving ideas, motive-forces in the guidance of conduct." (Dewey, 1909) How does (and should) music operate in a formal, school-like setting? - Lots of ideas in this space. Focusing on ensemble-based, individually-responsive models. - Balance between information and opportunities for application - Teacher-centric instruction vs. student-embracing instruction - *Outcome-based* vs. *competency-based* vs. *mastery-based* - Mastery-Based: Mastery-based learning is an instructional approach where students need to demonstrate a **deep level** of understanding of a **topic** or **subject** area before progressing onto another topic or subject area. - Competency-Based: The competency-based education (CBE) approach allows students to advance based on their ability to master a skill or competency **at their own pace** regardless of environment. - Outcome-Based: Outcome-based education (OBE) means clearly focusing and organizing everything in an educational system around **what is essential for all students to be able to do** successfully at the end of their learning experiences. ![https://www.d2l.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/img-obe-diagram.png](https://www.d2l.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/img-obe-diagram.png) - **9.1.2021 - Application** ### Identification of Lesson Focus - Fundamental music performance skills - Individual development in an ensemble frame - Tone Quality - Air Support / Bow Speed & Weight - Posture & Executive Control - Similarity and Uniformity: - Within individuals - Between individuals - Over time ### Group Work **BE CAREFUL OF:** **Monocausotaxophilia -** The love of single ideas that explain everything **PREP** Lab Ensemble #1 - **9.3.2021 - Lab Ensemble** LAB ENSEMBLE #1 ### Week 3 - **9.8.2021 - Information & Discussion** **TALK TO re: Spring 2022 Student Teaching** - ~~Corona, Rosa~~ - ~~Edwards, Bethany~~ - Klawinski, Ethan - ~~Leal, Heather~~ - ~~Vereide, Mitchell~~ **Ensemble Pedagogy** - **Why?** - One purpose of ensemble is to allow students a creative environment in which to engage with music in as many ways as possible. Ensemble pedagogy extends their toolkit by giving them the ability to interact more intentionally, responsively, and (*most importantly*) meaningfully with the repertoire and their peers. - **Ensemble pedagogy does not replace others aspects of music education** (e.g., musical thinking, personal development, repertoire selection, leadership development, social interaction, a feeling of belonging). **It can, however, strengthen other aspects of music education through its use.** - **What is "Ensemble Pedagogy"?** - Group vs. Individual musical skills - Chamber music *writ large* - Re-creative or creative - *both* have a place - **How do we approach this weird, abstract enterprise?** - Instead of ***x*** think about ***y*** - pitches ... the components to create accurate & precise pitch - notes ... the combinations of skill to produce correct notes - rhythms ... the understanding and awareness to create and adjust rhythm - line ... the constellation of skills required to communicate musically [MUED 4344 Ensemble Pedagogy.pdf](Daily%20Notes%2001eb7a0f9a3a4c119e20c9c6c3cfeb24/MUED_4344_Ensemble_Pedagogy.pdf) **Lab Ensemble** - Recap - What was the goal of the exercise? - What were the challenges to achieving that goal? - Reframe - What should the focus of time in front of an ensemble be? - How do we plan for that (or those) outcomes? - How do we make that happen, in reality? - Refocus for Sept. 17 - *Expected* focus vs. *actual* focus - **9.10.2021** - **9.12.2021** ### Week 4 - **9.13.2021 - Information & Framing** **Ensemble Pedagogy** vs. **Rehearsal Techniques** - Ensemble Pedagogy = Philosophy & Framework - Rehearsal Techniques = Execution **Very** fuzzy boundary in practice, useful to think of separately when learning. **Framing** - Ensemble Pedagogy:Rehearsal Techniques::Religion:Sermons - *Use analogies to check student understanding* **Rehearsal Techniques** - Most people think of these as “exercises,” or “approaches” - let’s use “tools” - Tools are used to improve student’s general- and specific skills *in the context of an ensemble, while also rendering (some) individual improvement.* - Tools to be used (single-purpose vs. versatile - like kitchen gadgets) - Each tool has a ‘maximum’ and numerous ‘minimum’ uses - gradations tied to the sophistication of the exercise as it relates to developed and/or combined fundamental skills. (ex. A hammer can be used as a stirring stick, door jam, or as a hammer) - Tools can (and should) be scalable things, where there is a basic, intermediate, and advanced version. The target of the tool is the same, but the complexity or sophistication changes. - Tools, here, can be both actual notation or methods/techniques applied to existing literature or notation. ex.) Remington Exercise vs. “Play rhythm on Concert F” - Some tools are distilled from the literature being performed, while others are “evergreen.” The latter address fundamental elements of instrument performance and genre practice and provide benefit to any work being performed. They can be adapted or reimagined to better address specific works, as well. - Scope and Sequence - Tools need to update as student’s skills improve. Think through more than one level of complexity/sophistication. - *Amanda Drinkwater* Marcus HS chart - How do we determine what level of complexity is appropriate? Optimal? - Age as proxy - Experience as proxy - Audition as proxy - Performance and interaction are the only sure-fire way, but they are backwards looking. The other three are predictive and future-oriented, which makes them (while less precise) more useful. - **9.15.2021 - Discussion & Sandboxing** **BE CAREFUL OF: Monocausotaxophilia -** The love of single ideas that explain everything Review: - **Ensemble Pedagogy** vs. **Rehearsal Techniques** - **Tools** - Maximal vs. minimal uses ("best" vs. "fringe") - Developmental Appropriateness / Sophistication - Methods & Approaches vs. Exercises - Literature-derived vs. "Evergreen" - Choosing **Tools**, **Levels**, **Sophistication**, **Origins** **New:** - Each area of musicianship has a range of tools that speak to its needs. The focus of your rehearsal, or foci of your rehearsal, should be the bulk of your skill-building and musical feedback throughout the rehearsal. - Use rehearsal recording (Waller HS - something good but with errors) to frame questions. Work through each layer of thought below to help students understand both how the ensemble's performance informs our planning & teaching AND how our musical thinking and model of sound frame how we navigate what we hear. - Reflective Questions: What does the group need today? Where are the overall areas of lower skill or success? How did they perform yesterday? Last week? Where do I want them to be in a week's time? - What aspects of musical thought seem to be the best lever (or levers) to improve the bulk of those issues? - What tools do I know (or can I create) whose best uses build ensemble skill in those areas? What approaches? What exercises? - What is the simplest version of the skill that would be effective, so I can focus attention on it in Daily Drill - What is the most accessible part of the literature that uses the skill? What is the part of the piece (or pieces) that needs attention the most. Sequence between these as needed. - As this skill, both in isolation and in its musical context in the literature, improves ... what are the other areas that need reinforcing? - Literature-derived - Evergreen - Exercise: Use ensemble performance model to help students work backward from performance → areas of concern → broad categories of musical thinking → tools → Daily Drill → application to literature → what's next - Make one of the tools focus on linear intervals - that is the exercise. Use MUSESCORE to create example - **9.17.2021** - **Application** ### Week 5 - **9.20.2021** Within an ensemble setting, how to assess individual effort? - Available information: ladder of inference - Scales of Assessment and Feedback in Ensemble setting - Level one: focus on the individual throughout an exercise, or rehearsal block - Level two: focus on a section or voice are similar fashion to above - Level three: mentally “crawl” the ensemble with your ears identifying individual problems (trickiest to master) **Mental Health** - self and students - **9.22.2021** Ladder of Inference (scaffolded) as a means to evaluate and assess ensemble performance. - **Ladder of Inference -** describes the thinking process that we go through, usually without realizing it, to get from a fact to a decision or action. - Utilize levels 1, 2, 3, 7 - Focus attention to both the obstructive aspect of selecting reality (creates blind spots) as well as the instinctive (go where you are most familiar). [The Ladder of Inference: How to Avoid Jumping to Conclusions](https://www.mindtools.com/pages/article/newTMC_91.htm) - Discuss implications to decision-making in immediate and reflective contexts. - Apply to categorical evaluations of performing groups (*below*) [https://youtu.be/1kC4OaYScfU](https://youtu.be/1kC4OaYScfU) [https://youtu.be/-ucrgsXUNn4](https://youtu.be/-ucrgsXUNn4) Use extracted rungs of ladder to scaffold student exploration: - - **9.24.2021 - Lab Ensemble** ### Week 6 [Marching Band] - **9.27.2021** Set foci and set parameters - Topics will be broad. Granularity will be low. - Will give opportunities for 'comparing notes' in discussion - **General Topics:** - Teaching large groups - pedagogy and logistics - Teaching individual students - pedagogy and affordances - Design - artistic, administrative, educational - Administration & Logistics - Marching band specific items - Band booster funding - District funding - Designers - Tech staff - Vendors - **Broad framing questions:** - "How does the activity of marching band fit into my music teacher identity?" - "How does the education of the student fit into their experience in the activity?" - "What are the outcomes being incentivized and to whom are they being incentivized? Discipline-wide? Group-level? Individual student? Individual director?" - What people's choices and behaviors are being rewarded within the system? - How closely do your values, and your program's values, align with the prevailing system? - Scaling participation and taking the good with the bad. - "What are my outcomes for both a student and a program overall within one year of marching band? Across four years of marching band?" - **9.29.2021** **Large Group Instruction** - Bisect music & visual where instruction is concerned - different enough that they require specialization. You *can* do both, but rarely at the same level of focus and recall — you're always going to favor one or the other. - What are some effective ways to evaluate large groups? - **Visual** - Generally - General impressions - surface - Specifically - Categories - Performance vs. Effect - Tips & Tricks - Depth of evaluation - Broad strokes → fine detail - Fuzzy detail → individual effort - **Musical** - Generally - Surface level (dynamics often go here) - Specifically - Different lines or voices - Interior architecture & warp/weft - Depth of evaluation - Broad strokes → fine detail - Fuzzy detail → individual effort - **Most feedback** should contain a mixture of general and specific information. Depth of evaluation should scale based on the focus of the information. The more the general is improved by the individual information, the stronger the feedback is overall. **Individual Instruction** - **Changed foci from group instruction:** Uniformity → accuracy, fluency, and precision. Here is where you increase the detail in the overall uniformity - by amplifying skill at the individual level. - **Mental picture, image, or model:** The higher the resolution of your internal model, the better your evaluation and feedback will be. - More repetition, targeted feedback, allow for processing time. - Application on Friday **Application & Discussion** - Self-identify as more comfortable visual or musical. - Break into small groups proportioned evenly for the distribution. - Work for 5 minutes to identify 2 areas of concern at the individual and group level within their captions. - Share. [CRHS 2012_05_30_1724 SCORE.pdf](Daily%20Notes%2001eb7a0f9a3a4c119e20c9c6c3cfeb24/CRHS_2012_05_30_1724_SCORE.pdf) [cy ranch fall 2012 part 1 charts 731 (revision 2).pdf](Daily%20Notes%2001eb7a0f9a3a4c119e20c9c6c3cfeb24/cy_ranch_fall_2012_part_1_charts_731_(revision_2).pdf) [CyRanch Opener .mov](Daily%20Notes%2001eb7a0f9a3a4c119e20c9c6c3cfeb24/CyRanch_Opener_.mov) - **10.1.2021** - What are some effective ways to evaluate large groups? - **Visual** - Generally - General impressions - surface - Specifically - Categories - Performance vs. Effect - Tips & Tricks - Depth of evaluation - Broad strokes → fine detail - Fuzzy detail → individual effort - **Musical** - Generally - Surface level (dynamics often go here) - Specifically - Different lines or voices - Interior architecture & warp/weft - Depth of evaluation - Broad strokes → fine detail - Fuzzy detail → individual effort - **Most feedback** should contain a mixture of general and specific information. Depth of evaluation should scale based on the focus of the information. The more the general is improved by the individual information, the stronger the feedback is overall. **Individual Instruction** - **Changed foci from group instruction:** Uniformity → accuracy, fluency, and precision. Here is where you increase the detail in the overall uniformity - by amplifying skill at the individual level. - **Mental picture, image, or model:** The higher the resolution of your internal model, the better your evaluation and feedback will be. - More repetition, targeted feedback, allow for processing time. ### Week 7 [Marching Band] - **10.4.2021** **Core Principles of Design** - Education - Design should support student's music education across as many aspects of musical learning as possible. *Only* touching on skill and training is the barest of minimums. - Engagement - The material you perform should be engaging for students, parents, directors, and the community. These groups will not be engaged to the same degree, but they need to have threads to hang on to in your show. - Craft - Your design should allow students to experience and see an iterative process of refinement - both in their performance and in the design itself. **Paradigms** - In-House - Benefits - Trade-Offs - Outsourced - Benefits - Trade-Offs **Design Understanding, Analysis, and Instruction** - Horizontal elements - A → B → C → D - Vertical elements - What is happening at the same time (sections, quadrants, etc...) **EXAMPLES** **Early Season** **Churchill HS** - BOA North Houston (2018) - 8th Place, Finals [https://youtu.be/0sso9ZvB9Tg](https://youtu.be/0sso9ZvB9Tg) **Churchill HS** - BOA San Antonio (2018) - 22nd Place, Prelims [https://youtu.be/sm6n1WMU9JQ](https://youtu.be/sm6n1WMU9JQ) ### **Traditions** **HBCU / Show Style -** Jackson State Univ. (2021) [https://youtu.be/upJRCBiuxBQ](https://youtu.be/upJRCBiuxBQ) **Military / Traditional -** Spring Hill HS (2019) [https://youtu.be/56_XQ7j0aaw](https://youtu.be/56_XQ7j0aaw) **Corps Style** - Carmel HS (2019) - 4th Place, BOA Grand Nationals [https://youtu.be/nxic-n4iD6g](https://youtu.be/nxic-n4iD6g) Marian Catholic HS (2001) - 5th Place, BOA Grand Nationals [https://youtu.be/oskBwrdOARo](https://youtu.be/oskBwrdOARo) - **10.6.2021** **Logistics & Administration** - **Transportation** - Timelines - Communication - Bus Requests - Load - 40-50 Students - 4-5 Parents - Cost - $700/Marching Contest - $350/Football Game - **Design** - Timelines - November - August (plus rewrites & adjustments) - Communication - Cost - Visual - Drill Design: $4,000 - $6,000 - Guard Work (Flag, Equipment): $2,000 - $3,000 - Choreography: $1,000 - $3,000 - Music - Wind Book: $2,000 - $5,000 - Battery Book: $2,000 - $3,000 - Front Ensemble Book: $2,000 - $3,000 - Electronics: $2,000 - $3,000 - Program Coordination - $2,000 - $4,000 - Equipment - Design - Props - Costuming - Guard - Battery - **Staffing** - Personnel - Vetting - Cost - $15 - $25/hour - Communication & Coordination - **Rehearsal & Curriculum** - Timelines - Communication & Coordination - **10.8.2021** [https://youtu.be/ZtaRuzrxhWA](https://youtu.be/ZtaRuzrxhWA) ### Week 8 - Individual Instruction - **10.11.2021** - Review dividual instruction materials - Kinds of assessment - Formative - Summarive - Reference Points - Norm referenced - Criterion referenced - Scales of Assessment and Feedback in Ensemble setting - Level one: focus on the individual throughout an exercise, or rehearsal block - Level two: focus on a section or voice are similar fashion to above - Level three: mentally “crawl” the ensemble with your ears identifying individual problems (trickiest to master) - Create a rubric for student performance - Three levels of achievement - Categories: tone, time, technique, musicianship - Use students on self perception and experience to frame language and expectation - **10.13.2021** [MUED 4344 Rubric 0.1 beta.pdf](Daily%20Notes%2001eb7a0f9a3a4c119e20c9c6c3cfeb24/MUED_4344_Rubric_0.1_beta.pdf) - **How do we use rubrics?** - Balance of positive & negative - What does the student need? - What do they respond well to? - What is your relationship with them like? - Formal assessment - Detailed text vs. symbols & indicators - Indicate things done incorrectly - Indicate things to do - Grades vs. categories - Informal assessment - "Compliment sandwich" - Repetition & Feedback - **Practice** - Students alerted: Corona (Trumpet), Hernandez (Flute), Paez (Horn), Velvin (Flute) - Feedback loops - Class participation - - **10.15.2021** - Review priorities - Address “tricks” - integrate with feedback loop(s) and cycles - Student performances - Breakout groups - update, adjust, revise rubrics ### Week 9 - Literature - **10.18.2021** [MUED 4344 Rubric 0.1 beta.pdf](Daily%20Notes%2001eb7a0f9a3a4c119e20c9c6c3cfeb24/MUED_4344_Rubric_0.1_beta%201.pdf) Revise **Individual Performance Rubrics** - Break in to small groups (3-4 student per) - Select one column, select one aspect of evaluation to change or add - Write it out in appropriate language at all three levels - Submit one copy per group ### Provocative Questions: **Question 1**: As ensemble music teachers, what is our orientation toward literature? Do we develop skill to play music, or do we play music to develop skill? Essentially, which end serves the other - technique to serve art or art to develop technique? **Intended takeaways:** - There is a balance to be struck between skill serving music and music building skill. - The relatedness of these two (e.g., what are the differences between skill being build away from literature and the skills utilized by the literature) will determine how efficient, effective, and educationally successful each work is with a group. - Two examples: - Ensemble needs to develop better clarity and balance. Choosing a work with 6-part harmony may be too much for a group that struggles with clarity in 2 parts. - Ensemble needs to work on articulation - both individually and as an ensemble. Choosing a work that only focuses on articulation (e.g., a march) would help to transfer this skill from Daily Drill to literature, but care should be taken to select a work that speaks to other areas of musical skill that students are proficient and need to develop in (but maybe to a lesser extent). **Question 2:** What criteria do we use to select literature for our groups? What makes for a great piece, and what makes for a great piece for our students? Where those don't align, where do you make the call? **Intended takeaways:** - Not all great pieces are great for the students you teach now. - Not all performances require the same level of detail and refinement, however — non-competitive venues allow for more exploration of works that might be on the outer edge of the ensemble's developmental abilities. - Don't compromise educational and artistic goals when selecting these works, but use them to create a different musical environment where excellence is still the goal, but you approach it in a different manner. - Where you have a work that would be great for your group (speaks to what they do well and what they need to work on), but it's not a piece that you think is great... search for a similar work (or other work by that composer). Don't default to a piece just because it 'fits your group' but satisfies no other criteria. - **10.20.2021** **Question 1:** What criteria do we use to select literature for our groups? What makes for a great piece, and what makes for a great piece for our students? Where those don't align, where do you make the call? **Intended takeaways:** - Not all great pieces are great for the students you teach now. - Not all performances require the same level of detail and refinement, however — non-competitive venues allow for more exploration of works that might be on the outer edge of the ensemble's developmental abilities. - Don't compromise educational and artistic goals when selecting these works, but use them to create a different musical environment where excellence is still the goal, but you approach it in a different manner. - Where you have a work that would be great for your group (speaks to what they do well and what they need to work on), but it's not a piece that you think is great... search for a similar work (or other work by that composer). Don't default to a piece just because it 'fits your group' but satisfies no other criteria. **Question 2:** How do we decide what pieces to program? How do we decide what pieces to consider? Where do we find this information? - Experience - Performer - Conductor - Audience member - Word of Mouth - Suggestions - Recommendations - Whisper-net - Observation - Other programs - Past performances - Comparison groups - Online Resources - Distributors - State Lists - Related websites - **10.22 - Lab Ensemble** [Holst - First Suite in Eb (score).pdf](Daily%20Notes%2001eb7a0f9a3a4c119e20c9c6c3cfeb24/Holst_-_First_Suite_in_Eb_(score).pdf) - Transcribe first 2 phrases for all instruments (A/B division) - Email Bertman/Bell re: Lab Ensemble Friday - Split group into two rooms - Figure out how to assess faster ### Week 10 - Literature & Budget - **10.25.2021** Contest literature selection & procedures - Update PML Committee names - Prep literature selection activity - Two pieces, one ensemble (HS 6A NV) - **10.27.2021** ### Where does the money come from? - **Local Funds** - 50% - **State Funds** - 44% - **Federal Funds** - 6% ### How is it spent? - Instruction - 60% - Admin. - 14% - Food Services - 6% - Plant Services - 10% - Other - 6% - Transportation - 3% ### Total Expenditures - Payroll - 68% - Other Operating - 17% - Debt Service - 13% - Capital Outlay - 2% ### Kinds of Budgets (School) - Management & Operations - Furniture, Fixtures, & Equipment - Transportation - Professional Services - Supplies & Equipment ### Sources of Funding - District - Boosters - Grants - Student Fees - **10.29.2021** [https://youtu.be/NsUqpr1IJfQ](https://youtu.be/NsUqpr1IJfQ) ### Week 11 - **Budget** - **11.1.2021** **District Budget Language** - Kinds of accounts - District or Campus Budget - Flow-Through - Above-district - Ways to purchase - Direct purchase - Purchase order **Budget Learning Lab** - List of needs - Budget line items - List of wants - Budget line items - Budget allotments - District - Booster - Student Fees - **11.3.2021** How do we budget? - What are **all** of our needs? - How much do these things cost? - What is the **priority** of the things needed? - How much does the budget allow for? - **Questions:** - In what cases can we move funds to cover? - In what cases can we ask our boosters? - In what cases do we need to wait until later? - In what cases can we ask for special funding? === STUDENT ACTIVITY === **Budget Assignment Overview** (7 minutes) - 11.5.2021 **Lab Ensemble** ### Week 12 - Instruments & Equipment - **11.8.2021** Frame unit of instruction: Financial, Education, Musical, Artistic Aspects - What are the commonly found "school owned" instruments? - Why are those instruments generally owned and maintained by the school? - What is your responsibility as a director where those instruments are concerned? - What is your responsibility as an educator where those instruments are concerned? - What is your responsibility as a musician where those instruments are concerned? How do you go about determining quantities of these instruments? - Minimal coverage - Average coverage - Ideal coverage How do you determine which instruments to purchase? - Personal experience - Repair shop inquiries - Crowd-sourced information [https://youtu.be/WM-8p99ymVM](https://youtu.be/WM-8p99ymVM) - **11.10.21** [https://youtu.be/LHvvfdiWeys](https://youtu.be/LHvvfdiWeys) - **11.12.21** [https://youtu.be/DfvYeH7G0PA](https://youtu.be/DfvYeH7G0PA) ### Week 13 - Technology - **11.15.21** [Instructional Technology Matrix - MUED 4344 Fall 2021.pdf](Daily%20Notes%2001eb7a0f9a3a4c119e20c9c6c3cfeb24/Instructional_Technology_Matrix_-_MUED_4344_Fall_2021.pdf) **Three main branches of technology in MUED** - **Instructional Technology** - Operates in two dimensions, with two poles - Individual ←→ Ensemble - Assessment ←→ Information - **Administrative Technology** - General Purpose - Office - Email, Spreadsheets, Word Processing - Learning Management Systems - School-Based - Google Classroom, Blackboard, Canvas, D2L - Communications - Program-Based - Remind, GroupMe, Band App, - Special Purpose - Charms Office Assistant - **Creative** - Notation Software - Finale, Sibelius, Notion, MuseScore - Sound Editing Software - GarageBand, LogicPro, ProTools, Audition, Audacity - Video Editing Software - Premiere Pro, Final Cut Pro, iMovie, DaVinci Resolve - Graphic Design Software - Adobe Photoshop, Adobe Illustrator, GIMP - Visual Design Software - Marching Band: Pyware [https://youtu.be/MKw-SKM7-HY](https://youtu.be/MKw-SKM7-HY) - **11.17.21** **Use cases** - Real-World Combinations: Instructional, Administrative, Creative [MUED 4344 Technology Integration Exercise Fall 2021.docx](Daily%20Notes%2001eb7a0f9a3a4c119e20c9c6c3cfeb24/MUED_4344_Technology_Integration_Exercise_Fall_2021.docx) [https://youtu.be/jajfjhpHX7U](https://youtu.be/jajfjhpHX7U) - **11.19.21 - Lab Ensemble** [https://youtu.be/iDZnsvto0oc](https://youtu.be/iDZnsvto0oc) [https://youtu.be/2bPdrJQXlic](https://youtu.be/2bPdrJQXlic) [https://youtu.be/TBisPtRwEkw](https://youtu.be/TBisPtRwEkw) [https://youtu.be/CdUZ5q0E_R0](https://youtu.be/CdUZ5q0E_R0) ### Week 14 - Fall Break(-ish) - **11.22.21** - Full Orchestra Zoom (Westwood HS) [https://youtu.be/wFCAT85UrsQ](https://youtu.be/wFCAT85UrsQ) ### Week 15 - Synthesis - 11.29 **Synthesis** - Pedagogy Focus <aside> 💡 Consider areas of focus within the course (MUED 4344) together and find their interrelations. Trace paths where one 'silo' interacts with others in ways that provide better understanding, insight, and tools to teach in the Secondary space. </aside> - **Music & Learning, Ensemble Pedagogy, Individual Instruction** - When we think about Ensemble Pedagogy, how does Music & Learning inform how we think and what we do? - **FOCUS:** Student learning needs and processes informing group-level activity. Daily Drill. Rehearsal material breakdown. Group-level assessment. Self-awareness and self-assessment (surface- and deep-level). - When we think about Individual Instruction, how does Music & Learning inform how we think and what we do? - **FOCUS:** Individual student learning needs and processes informing activity. Differentiation. Individual assessment & feedback loops. - When we think about Ensemble Pedagogy, how does Individual Instruction inform how we think and what we do? - **FOCUS:** The composite needs of individuals form a general target form framework of Ensemble Pedagogy planning and activity. - ***Mise en Place*, Teaching Fundamentals, Rehearsal Techniques** - What ways does the idea of *Mise en Place* interact with how we think and what we do around Teaching Fundamentals? - **FOCUS:** How do we arrange our thinking and teaching tools to be ready for whatever the rehearsal and/or students present us with? - What ways does the idea of *Mise en Place* interact with how we think and what we do around Rehearsal Techniques? - **FOCUS:** How can we anticipate the things we'll need to cover, how long they will take, and how we can use that time most effectively? - How might our experience with Teaching Fundamentals, Rehearsal Techniques, Ensemble Pedagogy, or Individual Instruction interact with the idea of *Mise en Place*? - **FOCUS:** How do we plan our day, week, month, or semester with all the different aspects of our teaching 'toolkit' receiving helpful amounts of space to function? - **Individual Instruction, Ensemble Pedagogy, Literature** - How do we integrate Literature into our experiences, planning, and framing of Individual Instruction & Ensemble Pedagogy? - **FOCUS:** What skills speak to literature selection? What literature suggests skills to develop? Where to draw the line? - 12.1 **Synthesis** - Administration Focus - ***Mise en Place*, Rehearsal Techniques, Budget & Logistics** - **Budget & Logistics, Instruments & Equipment, Instructional Technology** - 12.3 **Synthesis** - Role Playing - Single, Real-World Case Study - Groups of 4 or 5 - 5 minute introduction - 25 minutes of work - 15 minutes of sharing - 5 minutes integration

Literature.content: # MUED 4344 Plan - Fall 2023 ## Introduction & Technology - **August 21** (Monday) - Introduction, Mise en Place, Student Technology - Names around the room - Individual Questionnaire: [https://forms.office.com/r/XA0LvYZpTM](https://forms.office.com/r/XA0LvYZpTM) - Technology - Attendance - Exit Tickets - Canvas - Analog Technology - Mise en Place - Tools for Thinking - **August 23** (Wednesday) - Classroom Technology Technology Synthesis - **Prompts** “Your campus is pushing for technology integration into every classroom, every day. You are in the Spring Semester, preparing for UIL Concert & Sightreading, playing pieces that are developmentally appropriate for your students but are pushing them to deepen their musical thinking and technical skills. Describe one way that you could accomplish this while enhancing your existing rehearsal process and priorities.” “Over the past two years, your program has grown exponentially - from 50 students to 150! Your district will only create additional FTE (Full-Time Equivalent) positions when the average student/teacher ratio is 75:1 for more than two years. You have at least one year before an additional position is approved and another before that person can be hired and start work. Describe how you could use technology to extend and enhance your individual student instruction over the next two years.” - **Process** - Students randomly assigned prompt 1 or 2 - Students work on their responses (5 minutes) - Create groups of 4-5 students (homogenous) - Students share and edit their responses (10 minutes) - Students vote on the best of each group (2 minutes) - Each group presents one solution (20 minutes) - **August 25** (Friday) - Musical Technology ## Ensemble Pedagogy & Rehearsal Techniques - **August 28** (Monday) - Introduction & Overview - Priorities of Developing Musicians - Technical Skills - Musical Skills - Artistic Skills - Imaginative Skills - Present ensemble pedagogy (as we practice it) as a set of tools used to develop skills - Tools are priorities and understandings - Skills are real-life applications - Interweave strongly with individual skill development - Can actually boost and support individual skills in many cases - Creates a set of ensemble-based skills that empower and support student musicianship - Slideshow - **August 30** (Wednesday) - Basic Applications - We respond to sound but need to sort out the literature to make a plan. - Universal musical elements = constants - Unpack etude - Unpack score - **September 1** (Friday) - **LAB** ## Ensemble Pedagogy & Rehearsal Techniques - **September 4** (Monday) - LABOR DAY - **September 6** (Wednesday) - Basic Applications (Refined) **Go over Craft pages** Review Lab Teaching Experience - Self-evaluation - Peer-evaluation - Common problems & solutions - Instructional Solutions - Structural Solutions - Mise en Place - How to prepare - Why “quickfire” teaching? - How to prepare for Friday - Self-create simple mise - **September 8** (Friday) - **LAB** ## Rehearsal Techniques - **September 11** (Monday) - Rehearsal Structure - **Lesson Plan Components** - Curriculum - Goal(s) - Activities - Assessment - **Lesson Plan Layout** - Time - Students (#, instruments) - Attention (where to direct it, how long) - Plasticity (how much can we change in x amount of time/repetitions) - **Lesson Plan Design** - Central “spine” or “theme” - Long-term goals, short-term goals - Repetition & Self-Evaluation - Pacing & Variety - Age-appropriate - Different activities, same thread(s) - Quantity & Quality of Time - 5 focused minutes vs. 15 unfocused minutes - Attention Span vs. Optimal Pacing **Traditional Lesson Plans vs. Responsive Lesson Plans** - Opening, Unit 1, Unit 2, Unit 3 - Fundamentals, Repertoire - **September 13** (Wednesday) - Group and Individual Instruction, Feedback - **September 15** (Friday) - **Visitor - Deb Confredo** ## Logistics & Budget - **September 18 (Monday)** - Budget Overview [MUED 4344 - Budget Overview PDF.pdf](MUED%204344%20Plan%20-%20Fall%202023%20aceb7b173c124bb9911527812dd23aa8/MUED_4344_-_Budget_Overview_PDF.pdf) - **September 20 (Wednesday)** - Purchasing: What Do Things Cost? How Do We Budget? [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/18kEGwvhZ-mDfFsreiQ4BMW0-dNw-o9cAc9qUphcKHAM/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/18kEGwvhZ-mDfFsreiQ4BMW0-dNw-o9cAc9qUphcKHAM/edit?usp=sharing) - **September 22 (Friday)** - Calendars & Planning ## Logistics & Budget - **September 25 (Monday)** - Program Logistics: Rehearsal, Contest, Concert, Trip 1. **Core of Logistics:** Detailed, Long-Range Planning + Clear, Understandable, Consistent Communication - Schedules - Expectations - Feeds into Program Culture 2. **Needs of Logistics:** What, Where, When, Who 3. **Rehearsal Logistics** - W4 - Communication 4. **Contest & Concert Logistics** - W4 - Communication - Timeline 5. **Trip Logistics** - W4 - Communication - Timeline - Cost - September 27 (Wednesday) - Program Logistics: State, National, Planning, Communicating - September 29 (Friday) - **LAB** ## Marching Band / Full Orchestra - October 2 (Monday) - Translating Instruction from Indoor to Outdoor - Ensemble Pedagogy - Goals & Outcomes - Conceptual Framing - Fundamentals - Instruction - Effect Playing - What is it? - Examples ### Claudia Taylor Johnson - 2019 <YouTube Video: 2’23”> [https://youtu.be/k1r8Qxsjf6A?si=d9dubSp6hXjYKKi4&t=152](https://youtu.be/k1r8Qxsjf6A?si=d9dubSp6hXjYKKi4&t=152) ### Bluecoats 2019 <RMohney Plex: 0’24”> ### Hebron 2022 <Nick Nett File: 1’12”> ### Vandegrift 2022 <Nick Nett File: 0’00”> - October 4 (Wednesday) - Translating Instruction from Music to Visual - Music → Visual: Objectives, Goals, Outcomes - Where do concepts overlap? Where not? - Differentiate from visual style, similarities to visual system. - What is a system? Are they good? ### Examples Cavaliers 1991 [https://youtu.be/PysoO9p0OCU?si=P-H5-LZ1zpI7EisV](https://youtu.be/PysoO9p0OCU?si=P-H5-LZ1zpI7EisV) Star 1991 [https://youtu.be/TGybginT6qU?si=y-Vq0gaq7yxvN1kf](https://youtu.be/TGybginT6qU?si=y-Vq0gaq7yxvN1kf) Cavaliers 2004 [https://youtu.be/6TuKic5Lj5k?si=tyq8DitsfyTF50ac&t=278](https://youtu.be/6TuKic5Lj5k?si=tyq8DitsfyTF50ac&t=278) Cadets 1985 [https://youtu.be/iPYtdxUjizM?si=TJQHPkFLsj0TnOM8](https://youtu.be/iPYtdxUjizM?si=TJQHPkFLsj0TnOM8) Blue Devils 2017 [https://youtu.be/FO6d8zDf1Hg?si=XFtdgDaopL90xejE&t=55](https://youtu.be/FO6d8zDf1Hg?si=XFtdgDaopL90xejE&t=55) Bluecoats 2016 [https://youtu.be/o_uNLKip9xw?si=5TJaZzg-wSc0eHcE&t=14](https://youtu.be/o_uNLKip9xw?si=5TJaZzg-wSc0eHcE&t=14) Southern University 2023 [https://youtu.be/5DdWSCgnpS8?si=4muaNHtyHSX_6uQa&t=49](https://youtu.be/5DdWSCgnpS8?si=4muaNHtyHSX_6uQa&t=49) Texas A&M 2022 [https://youtu.be/-6pw8ltXZR0?si=1tsKclRVF0wgO0tY&t=92](https://youtu.be/-6pw8ltXZR0?si=1tsKclRVF0wgO0tY&t=92) - October 6 (Friday) - Budgets and Logistics How much does marching band cost? - Off-the-shelf / Custom, Bespoke - Roles and responsibilities - Design - Coordinator - Music Arranger - Visual Designer - Choreography - Color Guard - Choreography - Percussion Arranger - Sound Designer - Instruction - Color Guard Director - Tech Staff - Winds - Battery & Front Ensemble - Guard [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1SoGTjHnVTLJInCZ5S-Vj7Qh4qkDWPAP0Ftx6vjNHEtg/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1SoGTjHnVTLJInCZ5S-Vj7Qh4qkDWPAP0Ftx6vjNHEtg/edit?usp=sharing) - ## Marching Band / Full Orchestra - October 9 (Monday) [MUED 4344 Fall 2023](https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLPDrUaZWR7NvvAd5ghev1dZoWIUxWos6S&si=ibFz1o3ghcpdJWKE) **Visual Breakdown** - How to Extract Teachable Components - Movement Style - Straight Leg - Bent Leg - Chair Step - Drill Style - Dot-based - Form-based - Hybrid - October 11 (Wednesday) - October 13 (Friday) ## Literature - **October 16 (Monday)** - Literature Overview - What are the ways we use repertoire in an ensemble setting? - Curriculum - Skill Development & Challenge - Group Interaction - Artistic/Aesthetic Experience - How do we choose our literature? - Sourcing - Where are good places? Where are poor? - Sorting - Signal vs. Noise - Selecting - Signal + consideration (developmental appropriateness) - Rehearsing - Is the juice worth the squeeze? - What are factors we need to consider before selecting literature? - Time to performance - Weekly rehearsal & Sectional time - Student’s demonstrated skill level - Student’s demonstrated independent work level - October 18 (Wednesday) - Developmental Appropriateness - October 20 (Friday) - **LAB** ## Literature - October 23 (Monday) - Culturally Responsible Ensemble Teaching - October 25 (Wednesday) - Finding and Selecting Literature - October 27 (Friday) - Programming ## Ensemble Pedagogy & Individual Instruction - October 30 (Monday) - Solo & Ensemble; Rehearsal Structure, Full Ensemble & Sectionals - November 1 (Wednesday) - How to Run a Sectional - November 3 (Friday) - Integrating Individual Work into Sectionals ## Ensemble Pedagogy & Individual Instruction - November 6 (Monday) - Integrating Individual Feedback into Ensemble Rehearsal - November 8 (Wednesday) - Integrating Students Into Ensemble Rehearsal - November 10 (Friday) - **LAB** ## Ensemble Pedagogy & Individual Instruction - November 13 (Monday) - Equipment: How, What, Where, Why **BUDGET REFRESH** - November 15 (Wednesday) - Equipment: Developmental, Artistic **BUDGET REFRESH** - November 17 (Friday) - **LAB** ## Administration, Planning, Purchasing, and Pedagogy - November 20 (Monday) - **Conn Selmer & H&H Zoom** - November 22 (Wednesday) - THANKSGIVING - November 24 (Friday) - THANKSGIVING ## Administration, Planning, Purchasing, and Pedagogy - November 27 (Monday) - Calendars and Schedules - **Calendars** - How to plan - How to communicate - How to adjust - **Schedules** - How to plan - How to communicate - How to adjust - November 29 (Wednesday) - Communication and Planning - December 1 (Friday) - SYNTHESIS DAY! [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1YI6t9yG2G9pw6zeYpD_RRJcujFkqj7SoUmcfjIOmQ-4/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1YI6t9yG2G9pw6zeYpD_RRJcujFkqj7SoUmcfjIOmQ-4/edit?usp=sharing)

- Off-the-shelf / Custom, Bespoke - Roles and responsibilities - Design - Coordinator - Music Arranger - Visual Designer - Choreography - Color Guard - Choreography - Percussion Arranger - Sound Designer - Instruction - Color Guard Director - Tech Staff - Winds - Battery & Front Ensemble - Guard [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1SoGTjHnVTLJInCZ5S-Vj7Qh4qkDWPAP0Ftx6vjNHEtg/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1SoGTjHnVTLJInCZ5S-Vj7Qh4qkDWPAP0Ftx6vjNHEtg/edit?usp=sharing) - ## Marching Band / Full Orchestra - October 9 (Monday) [MUED 4344 Fall 2023](https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLPDrUaZWR7NvvAd5ghev1dZoWIUxWos6S&si=ibFz1o3ghcpdJWKE) **Visual Breakdown** - How to Extract Teachable Components - Movement Style - Straight Leg - Bent Leg - Chair Step - Drill Style - Dot-based - Form-based - Hybrid - October 11 (Wednesday) - October 13 (Friday) ## Literature - **October 16 (Monday)** - Literature Overview - What are the ways we use repertoire in an ensemble setting? - Curriculum - Skill Development & Challenge - Group Interaction - Artistic/Aesthetic Experience - How do we choose our literature? - Sourcing - Where are good places? Where are poor? - Sorting - Signal vs. Noise - Selecting - Signal + consideration (developmental appropriateness) - Rehearsing - Is the juice worth the squeeze? - What are factors we need to consider before selecting literature? - Time to performance - Weekly rehearsal & Sectional time - Student’s demonstrated skill level - Student’s demonstrated independent work level - October 18 (Wednesday) - Developmental Appropriateness - October 20 (Friday) - **LAB** ## Literature - October 23 (Monday) - Culturally Responsible Ensemble Teaching - October 25 (Wednesday) - Finding and Selecting Literature - October 27 (Friday) - Programming ## Ensemble Pedagogy & Individual Instruction - October 30 (Monday) - Solo & Ensemble; Rehearsal Structure, Full Ensemble & Sectionals - November 1 (Wednesday) - How to Run a Sectional - November 3 (Friday) - Integrating Individual Work into Sectionals ## Ensemble Pedagogy & Individual Instruction - November 6 (Monday) - Integrating Individual Feedback into Ensemble Rehearsal - November 8 (Wednesday) - Integrating Students Into Ensemble Rehearsal - November 10 (Friday) - **LAB** ## Ensemble Pedagogy & Individual Instruction - November 13 (Monday) - Equipment: How, What, Where, Why **BUDGET REFRESH** - November 15 (Wednesday) - Equipment: Developmental, Artistic **BUDGET REFRESH** - November 17 (Friday) - **LAB** ## Administration, Planning, Purchasing, and Pedagogy - November 20 (Monday) - **Conn Selmer & H&H Zoom** - November 22 (Wednesday) - THANKSGIVING - November 24 (Friday) - THANKSGIVING ## Administration, Planning, Purchasing, and Pedagogy - November 27 (Monday) - Calendars and Schedules - **Calendars** - How to plan - How to communicate - How to adjust - **Schedules** - How to plan - How to communicate - How to adjust - November 29 (Wednesday) - Communication and Planning - December 1 (Friday) - SYNTHESIS DAY! Instructional Paradigm.content: # General Instructional Paradigm **General Framing:** - If focusing on a skill (e.g., range, articulation) think about the simpler items that go into that skill (e.g., air, vibration, tongue placement). - If focusing on repertoire or exercises, think about the fundamental skills that allow the student to perform the material (e.g., tone, articulation) **Specific Steps** (Plan bottom to top, teach top to bottom) - **Set Objectives & Timeframes** - What do you need/want to get done? - How much time do you have to do it? - How many times will you see the students over your time with them (once a day, every other day, etc...)? - When working for a director or program, what do they want the students to be able to do **better** by the end of your sectional time? - **Material Study** - Look at, or think about, what you're going to be addressing. If it's music, identify the larger segments (phrases) and the challenges within them (e.g., technique, range, musical line). - With music or exercises, identify both the musical structure (e.g., where are phrases, what are the dynamics) as well as the fundamental skills that may be troublesome (e.g., tone is tricky here because of range, technique is tricky because of finger patterns). You will need to use both pools of knowledge to help the students. - **Chunking & Sequence** - Work on individual aspects of whatever you're addressing, whether that's individual measures, phrases, or simply one note or interval. - Organize these "chunks" into a logical sequence and work through them. - Ex.) - Perform A, Perform B, Perform C - give feedback after each - Perform A+B, Perform B+C - give feedback after each - Perform A+B+C - give feedback, break down as necessary - **Instruction** - Talk enough for the students to know you, know each other, and know what they need to do. Most people talk too much, so work to keep the students engaged through performance and feedback. - Basically, for every time you give the students feedback they should spend more than that amount of time playing - either individuals or as a group. - Try to keep your feedback to 1-2 things for the students to focus on the next time they perform. Less than that and they will only get better at the errors they notice, more than that they might zone out or forget things. - It's ok to allow students to have 'brain breaks' during sectionals, especially if its in the afternoon during Summer Band. Keep these to a minimum, and build in a restroom/water break into them. - I've found that telling the students how long they have and visibly setting a timer on my watch or phone helps to keep these 'on rails' - **Repetition & Feedback** - Can the students show improvement at least once? Can they make it consistent? - Most of the time, 2-3 repetitions of any one thing will show you if the students have improved. If they don't, move on to something else and revisit that skill later with a better plan. - **Desired Outcomes** - What does "better" sound/look like? - How much better should it be, given the amount of time?
